awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms and Impacts of De-regulating Aromatic Amino Acid Biosynthesis in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants produce aromatic amino acids (AAAs) from simple precursors, and use them to produce proteins, numerous natural products, including alkaloids, phenolics and additional organic compounds that have medicinal, nutritional and other useful properties. Understanding and improving the biosynthesis of AAAs will enhance the nutritional quality of food, achieve cost-effective production of medicines and enable sustainable production of industrial materials. The aims of this research are to gain fundamental knowledge concerning how plants regulate the production of AAAs, in order to precisely control the production of plant natural products that are derived from AAAs. "Pigment Art+" outreach activities will be conducted with K-12 students and their parents as a means of increasing the awareness of the importance of plant natural products. Colorful plant pigments derived from AAAs are used in this project as tools to inform the general public about the nutritional and pharmacological values of plant natural products. The activities are targeted for parents from communities that are low-income and underrepresented in science. This project also trains students and postdocs of diverse backgrounds, in collaborative interdisciplinary research that integrates biochemistry, structural and quantitative biology and the chemistry of plants.

Plants are particularly suited to produce AAAs and their derivatives since they naturally synthesize and accumulate a large quantity of AAA-derived compounds. How plants regulate AAA biosynthesis and coordinate the overall metabolic network to efficiently produce AAAs remains elusive.  A recent project identified plant enzymes that de-regulate the entry and final reactions of AAA biosynthesis, catalyzed by 3-deoxy-D-arabinoheptulosonate 7-phosphate synthase (DHS) and arogenate dehydrogenase (TyrA), respectively. Such novel regulatory enzymes of AAA biosynthesis are used to modulate this key intermediary pathway that connects central carbon metabolism and numerous plant natural product metabolic pathways. The major goals of this proposal are to define molecular mechanisms underlying the de-regulation of plant AAA biosynthesis and to determine their quantitative impacts on overall plant metabolic networks. The project specifically investigates the feedback regulation of DHS and TyrA variants, and quantitatively test their in planta roles in controlling AAA precursor supply. Dynamic carbon-13 CO2 labeling will be used for metabolic flux analysis. Time-dependent carbon-13 enrichment data will be used to estimate fluxes based on optimization of fit to a metabolic network model. This integrated molecular to network level analyses will provide a series of de-regulated DHS and TyrA variants, which will be tested in planta.  These experiments will generate prototype plant chemical platforms that will display enhanced AAA precursor supply.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced our fundamental understanding of how plants control the production of aromatic compounds and identified novel genetic mutations that can boost the conversion of CO2 into aromatics in plants. These discoveries and the importance of plant-derived chemicals were communicated with a broad audience of the general public through a number of public media and outreach activities. These findings were made by postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students, who gained in-depth multidisciplinary, collaborative research experience and further advanced their career in both academia and industry.

Plants use sunlight energy to convert atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) into diverse and abundant aromatic natural products. For instance, lignin, the major phenolic polymer of the plant cell wall, can account for up to 30% of total plant dry mass. Because of the high stability of aromatics, plant aromatic natural products can provide high-value chemicals, such as nutraceuticals and pharmaceuticals, and also serve as promising carbon storage to decrease CO2 concentration in the atmosphere. However, little was known how plants control biosynthesis of aromatic amino acids (AAAs), the major starting materials of aromatic plant natural products. The project integrated multidisciplinary approaches of enzyme biochemistry, forward and reverse genetics, metabolomics and metabolic flux analyses to address this key question.

The study uncovered that the first step of plant AAA biosynthesis, catalyzed by 3-deoxy-D-arabinoheptulosonate 7-phosphate synthase (DHS) enzymes, is subjected to highly-complex negative feedback regulation by the downstream products of the pathway. A forward genetic screening, using the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, further identified several point mutations, called suppressor of tyra2 (sota) mutations, that can release the negative regulation of DHS enzymes. Comparative biochemical analyses of arogenate dehydrogenase (TyrA) enzymes from various Caryophyllales plants, such as spinach, identified natural mutations that can relax the negative regulation of TyrA enzymes, which catalyze the last step of tyrosine biosynthesis. Introduction of these deregulated TyrA and DHS enzymes in Arabidopsis and Nicotiana plants drastically enhanced the production of AAAs and some plant chemicals derived from AAAs. Strikingly, the elevated carbon flux into the AAA biosynthetic pathways in these mutants and transgenic plants had limited impacts on overall plant growth and metabolism, such as biosynthesis of other amino acids and carbohydrates (e.g. sucrose). Instead, these plants increased the rate of CO2 assimilation through photosynthesis. Thus, the identified novel genetic mutations and enzyme variants can be utilized to boost the production of AAAs and their derived aromatic compounds in plants, while simultaneously reducing CO2 concentration in the air.

The findings have been published in nine journal articles so far, filed as US and international patents, and presented in various national and international conferences. The major finding of this project, "Altered (DHS) genes helps plants absorb more CO2, produce useful (aromatic) compounds", was highlighted in a variety of news media and reached well beyond the scientific community.

To explain and discuss with the general public the importance of plant natural products, plant pigments were used as attractive tools to visualize and learn various properties of plant-derived chemicals. Building upon the "Pigment-Art" outreach that the Maeda lab has developed previously, the members of this project creatively came up with various outreach activities, such as "Who stole my smoothie!?", where children became an investigator to distinguish pigments with similar colors (e.g. betalains vs. anthocyanins) through experimentation. During the COVID-19 pandemic, an online video, "Discovering Differences in Plant Pigments", was generated to provide at-home hands-on experiments and help K-12 students learn about the properties and diversity of plant pigments through basic chemical analyses. The team also assembled and delivered take-home "Pigment-Art" kits and carried out zoom outreach activity, where children and parents studied different properties of plant pigments and their importance in our health and well-being. Many of these outreach activities were carried out with schools and community centers off campus to increase opportunities to interact with children from underrepresented groups.

The project also provided training opportunities for three postdocs, three graduate students, and seven undergraduate students, which include five female and one underrepresented members. Through the multidisciplinary collaborative research, the trainees (including undergraduate students) carried out independent research related to plant AAA biosynthesis and learned how to design and execute experiments, critically analyze data, re-evaluate hypotheses, refine the project, and present the findings in a logical fashion. The outreach activities provided them opportunities to explain their science to a broader audience. The postdoc and graduate students also gained mentoring skills by supporting the work of undergraduate students. The well-rounded training provided the foundation to further advance their career not only in academia but also in industries.
